In a geometric sense, the dot product between a weight vector and an input vector can be interpreted as the projection of the input vector onto the weight vector. The dot product is a scalar value that represents the amount of the weight vector that is aligned with the input vector.

In the context of logistic regression, the dot product is used to project the input vector onto the decision boundary, which is represented by the weight vector. The sign of the dot product determines which side of the decision boundary the input vector lies on. If the dot product is positive, the input vector is on one side of the decision boundary, and if the dot product is negative, the input vector is on the other side of the decision boundary.

The absolute value of the dot product can also be used to measure the distance between the input vector and the decision boundary. The distance between the input vector and the decision boundary is the absolute value of the dot product divided by the magnitude of the weight vector. This distance can be useful in interpreting the confidence of the classification.

In summary, the dot product between a weight vector and an input vector in logistic regression can be interpreted as the projection of the input vector onto the weight vector. The sign of the dot product determines which side of the decision boundary the input vector lies on and the absolute value of the dot product can be used to measure the distance between the input vector and the decision boundary. This distance can be useful in interpreting the confidence of the classification.
